body_text.text: countries, areas and territories, with a total of over 575,000 25 confirmed cases and over 26,000 deaths (WHO, 2020b) . 26 Similar to SARS-CoV and the Middle East Respiratory 27 Syndrome (MERS-CoV) virus, SARS-CoV-2 is zoonotic virus. 28 Zoonotic viruses can spread from non-human animals to 29 humans. In this case, Chinese horseshoe bats (Rhinolophus 30 sinicus) are the most probable origin and pangolin (Manis 31 javanica) as an intermediate host (Li et al., 2020) . 32 The asymptomatic incubation period of the virus is estimated 33 to be between 2 and 12 days; however, up to 24 days incubation 34 period was reported in some studies (C.C. Lai et al., 2020) . The 35 most common symptoms of coronavirus disease are fever, tired-36 ness, dry cough and shortness of breath. More than 80% of cases 37 are mild and recover from the disease without needing special 38 treatment. However, around 15% of cases are categorised as 39 severely ill and the remaining 5% are categorised as critically 40 ill. In severe and critical cases, acute respiratory disease can lead 41 to pneumonia, kidney failure, and even death. 42 Although it is still early to determine the case fatality ratio 43 (CFR); today it is estimated to be over 4.5% (WHO, 2020b transmission is now believed to be mainly via saliva associated 52 respiratory droplets and contact transmission. However, fecal-53 oral transmission is possible as SARS-CoV-2 was identified in 54 the stool of patients (Holshue et al., 2020) . 55 Vertical transmission (from mothers to their new-borns) 56 however, is not yet confirmed (H. Chen et al., 2020) . More-57 over, aerosol and fomite transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is also 58 plausible as the virus can remain viable and infectious in aero-59 sols for at least three hours and on surfaces for days (van 60 Doremalen et al., 2020) . Transmission from asymptomatic 61 COVID-19 carriers possibility was also reported (Bai et al., 62 2020; C.-C. Lai et al., 2020) . 63 To date, real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain 64 reaction (rRT-PCR) test is utilised for the qualitative detection 65 of nucleic acid from SARS-CoV-2 in upper and lower respira-66 tory specimens obtained through nasopharyngeal and/or 67 oropharyngeal swabs. Viral RNA has been also isolated from 68 the plasma of some patients (Huang et al., 2020) . . Moreover, salivary gland epithe-79 lial cells can potentially be infected by SARS-CoV and become 80 a major source of the virus in saliva (Liu et al., 2011) . Even 81 after patient recovery, recusancy during the convalescence per-82 iod was reported (D. Chen et al., 2020) . This is plausible since 83 the presence of some virus strains in saliva for as long as 84 29 days have been reported in the literature (Barzon et al., 85 2016; Zuanazzi et al., 2017) . 86 In addition to blood and salivary contamination, the 87 majority of routine rental treatments generate significant 88 amounts of droplets and aerosols. This is usually related to 89 the utilisation of devices and equipment such ultrasonic sca-90 lers, air-water syringes and air turbine handpieces. in China during the epidemic; demand for urgent dental treat-94 ment decreased by only 38% (Guo et al., 2020) . This shows 95 that the public need for urgent dental care even during this 96 pandemic will always be essential. Rubber dam should be used whenever possible as this will 217 significantly reduce the spread of microorganisms 218 (Cochran et al., 1989) . Otherwise, the treatment should be postponed and pharmaco-253 logic management of the pain and/or infection should be con-254 sidered. Moreover, the dental treatments categories in Table 1,   255 covers most but not all of the dental cases. Therefore, case and 256 treatment categorisation should always be considered by the 257 practitioner. 258 It is hoped that the guidelines proposed in this work will 259 help in the management of dental care around the world dur- Dis. FIGREF7.text: , no universal protocol or guideline is available for den-229 tal care provision to active or suspected COVID-19 cases. In 230 fact, no universal guidelines are available for dental care pro-231 vision during the times of any epidemic, pandemic, national or 232 global disaster. Due to that lack of a standard, dental care pro-233 vision has completely stopped or significantly decreased in sev-234 eral affected countries. Oxygen therapy is the major intervention for patients 47 with severe cases. Critical cases management on the other hand 48 is case dependant and will usually need intensive care (Chughtai 49 and Malik, 2020; Guan et al., 2020; WHO, 2020c). Dental Treatments Categories     
A B C D E
Emergency   Non-urgent Elective
Unstable maxillofacial fractures that can compromises the patient's airway.* Urgent conditions that can be managed with minimally invasive procedures and Urgent conditions that need to be managed with invasive and/ or aerosol-generating procedures   
without aerosol generation Severe dental pain (7) from pulpal inflammation that requires tooth extraction.** Severe dental pain (7) from pulpal inflammation that need to be managed with aerosol generating procedures.** Removable dentures adjustments or repairs. Initial or periodic oral examinations and recall visits.
   
 Severe dental pain (7) from fractured vital tooth that can be managed without aerosol generation.** Severe dental pain (7) from fractured vital tooth that need to be managed with aerosol generating procedures.**  Aesthetic dental procedures.
Diffuse soft tissue bacterial infection with intraoral or extraoral swelling that can compromises the patient's airway.* Asymptomatic fractured or defective restoration.  
    
Uncontrolled postoperative bleeding.*  Dental trauma with avulsion/ luxation that need invasive/   
 Dental trauma with avulsion/ luxation that can be minimally managed without aerosol generation. Aerosol Generating Procedures Asymptomatic fractured or defective fixed prosthesis. Restorative treatment of asymptomatic teeth.
  
 Surgical postoperative osteitis or dry socket that can be managed without aerosol generation.* Deboned fixed prosthesis cleaning and temporary cementation. Asymptomatic fractured or defective orthodontic appliance. Extraction of asymptomatic teeth.
   
    
 Pericoronitis or third-molar pain that can be managed without aerosol generation. Removable dentures adjustments for radiation/ oncology patients. Chronic periodontal disease. Orthodontic procedures other than those in category B/C.
    
 Stable maxillofacial fractures that requires no intervention.*    
  Fractured or defective fixed prosthesis causing soft tissue injury.  Routine dental cleaning and preventive therapies.
    
  Acute periodontal disease.   
 Localised dental/periodontal abscess that can be managed without aerosol generation   Replacement of missing tooth/teeth with fixed or removable prosthesis.
    
 Fractured or defective fixed orthodontic appliance causing soft tissue laceration.   Dental implant surgery.

TABREF3.text: * Usually managed by oral and maxillofacial surgeons. ** Pain assessment is carried out using the Universal Pain Assessment Tool (UPA).
